thread.title: NBA rookie puts Delly in the hot seat
thread.title_full: NBA rookie puts Delly in the hot seat

title: NBA rookie puts Delly in the hot seat
text:
Matthew Dellavedova’s starting spot in jeopardy due to Malcolm Brogdon’s impressive play an hour ago @olgunuluc Source: FOX SPORTS MATTHEW Dellavedova’s recent injury has given Malcolm Brogdon the opportunity to continue proving his worth, and it could mean trouble for the Australian guard. 
Brogdon finished with a triple-double — 15 points, 11 rebounds, and 12 assists — in his second career start, helping the Bucks to a 116-96 win over the Bulls, and he’s made a convincing case that he should be starting more often. 
Early in training camp, it was Dellavedova who locked up a spot as the starting point guard, proving to be a reliable, championship-winning presence around a young team with immense potential. 
While the Maryborough-native has performed admirably, Brogdon has more than exceeded his 36th overall selection in the 2016 draft, and has looked extremely comfortable playing with the starting unit, particularly during Dellavedova’s stint on the sidelines. 
PODCAST! The guys are joined by Brooklyn Nets Assistant General Manager Trajan Langdon to talk Duke, his time at CSKA Moscow, and the Nets organisation, before Golden State Warriors guard Ian Clark jumps on to talk about his rise up the team’s rotation, and why the Warriors’ chemistry is so good. 
Subscribe to the podcast on iTunes by CLICKING HERE. Matthew Dellavedova. Source: Getty Images 
The rookie is averaging 8.3 points and 3.6 assists per game, and has been outplaying Dellavedova over the past month, particularly with his shooting. 
During December, Brogdon has shot 51.5 percent from the field and 50 percent from beyond the arc, compared to Dellavedova’s 37.6 percent from the field and 33.3 percent from behind the three-point line. 
“We’re holding him back; blame it on the coach,” Bucks head coach, Jason Kidd, said of Brogdon after Sunday’s (AEDT) win. 
“He’s a special person. For him to be asked to start and run the team with Giannis and Jabari, he has handled everything we’ve thrown at him. He was great tonight.” 
While Dellavedova has proven himself to be the more capable playmaker — averaging 5.6 assists per game, compared to Brogdon’s 3.6 — the Bucks’ starting point guard position seems to be better suited to a guard who’s more scoring-oriented. 
The team’s leading assist-man isn’t its point guard; it’s its ‘point forward’, Giannis Antetokounmpo, who’s averaging 5.9 assists per game. With the ‘Greek Freak’ running the point, it makes sense to surround him with scorers, which is why Jabari Parker is in the midst of a career scoring year, and Tony Snell’s three-point shooting is improving with every month. Malcolm Brogdon is in impressive form. Source: AP 
The question isn’t whether Dellavedova is a starter in the NBA, because he has the ability to start for several teams. The question is: is Dellavedova the right type of player to be starting for this team? 
With Brogdon proving himself to be the more versatile, efficient scorer of the pair, he’s been able to excel next to a play-making, ball-dominant wing like Antetokounmpo. 
On the other hand, Dellavedova, who has impressed, may be better suited to return to his ‘super sub’ role, running the point for the team’s second unit. 
Dellavedova’s hamstring injury isn’t expected to keep him out for much longer, so, when he’s ready to return to the court, Jason Kidd has an important decision to make. 
Olgun Uluc covers basketball for Fox Sports Australia. Twitter: @OlgunUluc
